newsitem.title: USA: Japan joins EC to overturn Massachusetts' Burma law.
newsitem.headline: Japan joins EC to overturn Massachusetts' Burma law.

text.p: Japan has joined the European Union in filing a complaint with the World Trade Organisation over a Massachusetts law that denies state contracts to businesses doing business in Burma, the U.S. Trade Representative's office said Monday.
"Japan has formally requested to join the consultations," a spokesman for the trade representative said, adding that talks were scheduled in Geneva for the week of July 21.
The 15-nation EU last month requested settlement consultations through the WTO last month on the law, which went into effect Jan. 1.

"We're not surprised that Japan has joined the EU complaint," said Massachusetts state Representative Byron Rushing who co-authored the Burma bill. "I am disappointed and disturbed that the real issue is being ignored.
"The real issue is: How do we restore democracy in Burma?" he said, adding that was the reason for the legislation.
The Massachusetts law imposes a pricing penalty on state procurements from companies that do business in Burma.
